Intro.text:
This page only applies to contrast agents usually used for CT scans. MRIs with contrast use gadolinium, which can cause
nephrogenic systemic fibrosis
in patients with renal dysfunction.

Background.text:
Often defined as
creatinine rise
of more than 0.5mg/dL or ≥25% above baseline
[1]
Vasoconstriction leading to ischemia in the deeper portion of the outer medulla
Toxic to kidney tubular cells, inducing vacuolization, change in mitochondrial function, and apoptosis
Less likely to occur with low and iso-osmolar contrast agents

Healthy_Patients.text:
Not likely to occur in patients with a Cr<1.5 or a GFR >60ml/min
[2]
[3]

Impaired_Renal_Function.text:
Administration should follow your local hospital protocols
Less likely to occur in iso-osmolar contrast agents (iodixanol/Visipaque) and contrary to traditional teaching, maybe not even an occurrence in patients with creatinine greater than 2.0mg/dL.
[4]

Risk_Factors.text:
Renal disease
Recent contrast study within 72 hrs
Hypotension
Dehydration
DM
Multiple myeloma
Age > 70
Hypertension
Hyperuricemia
Diuretics

Clinical_Features.text:
Decreased urine output
0.5mg/dl absolute or >25% relative increase in serum creatinine 48-72hrs after contrast exposure

Contrast_induced_complications.text:
Contrast induced allergic reaction
Contrast-induced nephropathy
CT contrast media extravasation
Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis

Contrast induced allergic reaction
Contrast-induced nephropathy
CT contrast media extravasation
Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis

Management.text: Hallmark of management is prevention in at-risk patients.

Hydration.text:
Isotonic hydration with
normal saline
1-1.5L (15ml/kg) prior to the contrast load in patients with impaired renal function may lessen the chances of developing CIN
[5]
[6]
[7]
If suspect the development or confirm the diagnosis continue adequate hydration to maintain urine output of 0.7cc-1cc/kg
Early research suggests a potential benefit for forced
furosemide
diuresis (300ml/h) while continuing
intravenous hydration fluids
(0.5mg/kg) but should be performed in consult with radiologist and nephrologist
[8]

N-acetylcysteine.text:
Is not useful for preventing CIN
[9]
[7]

Other_Measures.text:
Low osmolar contrast agents
Bicarbonate
infusion
Hypertonic saline
